subject: Photography
title: Additive vs. Subtractive Color
description: A 60-second lesson on Additive vs. Subtractive Color.

hook.text: Mix red, green, and blue paint and you get mud. Mix red, green, and blue light and you get white. Why?

buildup.text: Light uses additive color mixing ‚Äî adding wavelengths together. More light means brighter, whiter results.

discovery.text: Paint and ink use subtractive color. Pigments absorb wavelengths, subtracting light. More pigment means darker.

twist.text: Screens display additive RGB. Printers use subtractive CMYK. The same photo can look different on screen vs. print.

climax.text: Photographers must understand both systems. Your camera captures in RGB. Your print lab converts to CMYK.

punchline.text: Light adds up to white. Ink adds up to black. Know which you're using.

quiz.question: Why might a photo look different on screen versus in print?
options: Screens use additive RGB light while printers use subtractive CMYK ink
